{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3384082,"name":"","username":"Salazarv24","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/90db22/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T19:00:31.585Z","cooked":"

Hello. Recently we bought ourselves 2 Raspberry Pi 5’s and 2 Camera Modules to go along with them. Our main idea was implementing object detection within Photonvision but we have seen that it is mainly supported for Orange Pi 5’s. We have also seen that detecting objects within the Raspberry Pi operating system is possible. Still, we have yet to find how to get values from this detection and how to implement it and run it alongside the robot’s code.

Our question is:
Is it possible to implement object detection with a Raspberry Pi? If so, how?

From what I’ve seen most teams use YOLOv8

Is there a reason you are trying to run it through photonvision? I’ve had success in non frc projects just writing a python script that runs yolov8 and processes the output, and then sends it somewhere (in your case, over network tables most likely)

What specifically are you trying to do with object detection? Is it just detecting presence, detecting angle (like the old color pipelines), or are you trying to pose estimate game objects?

One option is to use basic image processing (color, size, shape, etc.) with the OpenCV library on a Raspberry PI for object detection. I don’t know of any plug-and-play solutions for FRC. You’d have to roll your own code, but it’s not too hard. Code could be Python, Java, or C++. There are probably other options as well.

This approach would not have the complex object detection power of YOLO or other NN solutions. However, looking for the basic shape of a gamepiece of known color isn’t a difficult object detection task. Simple image processing should get you high framerates on a Raspberry PI and replace NN training with some OpenCV filter tuning.

Here’s a recent example of OpenCV image processing for Note detection. There is a section of the WPILib Docs on vision with a Raspberry PI that has good information on integrating the PI with a robot.

Open Computer Vision Library","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-teams-implement-object-detection-with-a-raspberry-pi-5/465999/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3384471,"name":"","username":"Salazarv24","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/90db22/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-11T15:11:17.910Z","cooked":"

That seems great, will work on this once I get the opportunity on Monday. I’ll research this weekend to see how I may do it. One question that I have is: Will I be able to get values from these detections? Is the downside of tuning the HSV values worth it? (I think it is, just want to know other’s opinions)

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-05-11T15:11:17.910Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":41.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":465999,"topic_slug":"how-do-teams-implement-object-detection-with-a-raspberry-pi-5","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22261,"username":"paulonis","name":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63918,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-teams-implement-object-detection-with-a-raspberry-pi-5/465999/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3384478,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-11T15:36:34.841Z","cooked":"

If by “get values”, you mean finding the x and y image coordinates of the center of your gamepiece bounding box, then the answer is yes. These can be passed to NetworkTables to use for targeting. Getting a distance to target is also possible, but would require some calculations and calibration that typically uses the size of the bounding box and the y coordinate of the bounding box center.

Tuning HSV values usually isn’t too difficult. Orange Notes are sufficiently different from red bumpers that tuning to detect one and reject the other isn’t too bad. Yellow cones and purple cubes from last year were easy. Red and blue balls from the year before that were not easy because of the similarity to bumper colors. Filtering on shape and size was critical for those gamepieces.

Just use photonvision’s rpi build for this. They have color detection pipelines built in and it will be much less of a hassle then trying to make a custom solution. But if you want to learn and have some fun then by all means mess around with opencv, photonvision will be a safety net.

Dataset Colab has prebuilt YOLO models for note detection. Might be easier than setting up an opencv pipeline.

I want to ask, which one will run better? I have used Photonvision before and it is kind of buggy, but lack any knowledge of OpenCV’s performance.

We ran photonvision last year and this year for color detection on our raspberry pi 3/4. It worked well, I recall a couple issues but we solved them by simply updating to a patched version. For the most part the people at photonvision have done a great job making a reliable vision processing subsystem, would highly recommend if you want a more plug and play option.
